snippet: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.
abstract: Cause of blast at fertilizer plant in West, Tex, that destroyed a significant piece of the town and killed as many as 15 people and injured 180 others remains unclear; federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration records show last time agency inspected plant, 28 years ago, it found five violations, including ones involving improper storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia and improper respiratory protection for workers.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from West, and John Schwartz from New York. Reporting was contributed by Clifford Krauss in West; Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Christine Hauser, Henry Fountain and Ravi Somaiya in New York; Steven Greenhouse in Austin, Tex.; and Ian Urbina in Washington.

lead_paragraph: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.

headline.seo: Huge Blast at Texas Fertilizer Plant Kills at Least 5
headline.main: Plant Explosion Tears at the Heart of a Texas Town
headline.print_headline: Blast at Plant Tears at Heart Of Texas Town
